comment.author: 45586426@N06
comment._content: A-6E Intruder 158533 in extremely flamboyant color scheme over gull gray and white with white radome and black Modex code 502 on side of nose. Large colorful tail code AG of Carrier Air Wing Seven (CVW-7) Picture probably dated August 1972. A color profile of A-6E Intruder 158533 within these two internet webpages: www.gaetanmarie.com/en/a6.htm wp.scn.ru/en/ww3/a/788/3/2/15 In 1972, VA-65 received brand-new A-6E Intruders in replacement of its A-6As and promptly painted them in squadron colours as shown here on BuNo 158533. 1972 picture similar to SDASM 'flickr' pic with A-6E 158533 included: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:A-6Es_VA-65_in_flight_1972.jpeg Two Grumman A-6E Intruder BuNo 158531 & 158533 from VA-65 'Tigers' in flight in August 1972. VA-65 was assigned to CVW-7 aboard CVA-62 USS Independence (having transitioned from the A-6A to A-6E after returning from a 1972 deployment) As yet there is no internet accessible record of A-6E 158533 with VA-65 after 1972. Built as an A-6E Intruder from outset, Bu No 158533 was possibly from a 1971 production batch as its US Navy official purchase date was 6 January 1972. 1976 pictures of A-6E 158533: www.abpic.co.uk/photo/1221874/ www.abpic.co.uk/photo/1016503/ www.airport-data.com/aircraft/photo/347985.html www.airport-data.com/aircraft/photo/347987.html A-6E 158533 VA-176 'Thunderbolts' Modex 500, code AE of CVW-6. CV-66 USS America. Mildenhall Air Fete 1976 RAF Mildenhall, Suffolk, England UK - 4th July 1976 1976 record for A-6E 158533: www.gonavy.jp/CVW6-AE1976.html A-6E 158533 was part of VA-176 'Thunderbolts' Modex 500 with CVW-6 (code AE) from April 15 to October 25, 1976 aboard CV-66 USS AMERICA for an Atlantic Ocean & Mediterranean Sea patrol. 1977 pictures of A-6E 158533: www.abpic.co.uk/photo/1153825/ www.airport-data.com/aircraft/photo/303328.html www.airport-data.com/aircraft/photo/303325.html www.airliners.net/photo/USA---Navy/Grumman-A-6E-Intruder/... A-6E 158533 VA-65 'Tigers' Modex 503 tail code AG of CVW-7 3 September 1977 Royal Naval Air Station Yeovilton Air Day, Yeovil, Somerset, England, United Kingdom. Unfortunately as yet there is no internet 'GO!NAVY' record of A-6E 158533 with VA-65 for years 1977 to 1980. 1984 record for A-6E 158533: www.gonavy.jp/CVW11-NH1984.html This was with CVW-11 (code NH) on board CVN-65 USS ENTERPRISE for a Western Pacific & Indian Ocean voyage between May 30, 1984 & December 20, 1984. A-6E 158533 is recorded with VA-95 'Green Lizards' as Modex 511. Sometime during the mid 1980's A-6E 158533 was modified and updated to take the Hughes 'Target Recognition and Attack Multisensor' or 'TRAM' containing a Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR), laser designator and laser receiver to enable target identification/designation and use of laser guided bombs or other weapons. articles.janes.com/articles/Janes-Avionics/AN-AAS-33-Targ... Some time in 1987 A-6E TRAM 158533 was transferred across the Pacific Ocean to join forward based VA-115 'Eagles' as part of permanently forward deployed CVW-5 (code NF) based at NAF Atsugi Japan. Also forward deployed and home ported at Yokosuka, Japan was CV-41 USS MIDWAY, the air wing carrier. www.gonavy.jp/CVW-NF2f.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1987.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1988.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1989.html www.gonavy.jp/CVW5-NF1990.html In 1987 A-6E TRAM 158533 replaced an A-6E as Modex 512 A-6E TRAM 158533 VA-115 'Eagles' became Modex 505 tail code NF of CVW-5 until some time in 1990 when itself was replaced. There is also a reference that A-6E 158533 was once AG-502 on board CVN-69 USS Dwight D. Eisenhower. But there is as yet no other evidence to prove this: www.oocities.org/iek_17/tables/usnavy.htm A-6E 158533 had a reasonable number of flight hours and carrier landing/launches so was chosen to be one of those for rebuild, re-wing and modernization, however events took a different turn and now……. the remains of the fuselage core of A-6E 158533 is in the ocean at a location known as “Intruder Reef” off the Florida coast. By the time of disposal A-6E 158533 had accumulated 4527 flight hours, 1176 Catapult Launches (CATS) and 1195 carrier arrested landings (TRAPS). Go here for list with notes of all Intruders built: www.intruderassociation.org/losses.html Click on; “Every A-6 that was ever built” (Courtesy of the “Intruder Association”) Many are color highlighted to indicate outcome, those in blue went for "disposal in the environment". The US Navy created a program to replace A-6 wing boxes after finding fatigue damage. Boeing Military Aircraft won a contract to produce one-piece, graphite epoxy composite wings for 120 aircraft. Grumman-St. Augustine retained control over final reassembly of 72 planes, plus making 120 kits to mate Boeing wing to fuselage. A number of A-6s were waiting at Northrop Grumman’s plant in St.Augustine, Florida for wing boxes to be changed & airframes overhauled when the remainder of the order was cancelled. Florida State Department of Environmental Protection and the Navy agreed for the remaining A-6’s to be disposed of by dumping in the ocean. They were completely stripped and decontaminated before leaving to become an artificial reef and marine habitat off the Florida coast called “Intruder Reef”. On June 16 1995, a barge load of 26 Intruders were craned into the water 25 miles off St. Augustine. Five days later, another 18 followed. myfwc.com/docs/Conservation/REEFS.pdf 'State of Florida Artificial Reef Locations' ST. JOHNS 6/16/1995 INTRUDER REEF 44827.6 61871.8 2954.186 8045.012 23 PIECES OF A-6 AIRCRAFT, 1ST OF TWO LOADS, 33 TOTAL 105 8 GPS ST. JOHNS 6/21/1995 INTRUDER REEF 44829.4 61872.2 2954.339 8048.167 17 NUMBERED PIECES OF A-6 INTRUDER AIRPLANES, 2ND OF TWO LOADS 104 8 GPS Internet links to locations: www.thiswaytothe.net/reefs/pages/intruder-1-reef-st-johns... www.thiswaytothe.net/reefs/pages/intruder-2-reef-st-johns... You will be amazed at the hundreds of thousands of tons of material that has and is being dumped off the Florida coast. Including destroyers, ships, tugboats and an aircraft carrier, USS ORISKANY. Go here for pictures of Intruder hulks being laid to rest: www.intruderassociation.org/ www.intruderassociation.org/intruder_reef.html www.intruderassociation.org/pdf/burial_at_sea.pdf (Courtesy of the ‘Intruder Association’) (Note; GO!NAVY' website info is gathered on a purely voluntary basis and may be fragmentary or incomplete, it’s extremely fortunate when records matching individual airframe serial numbers to units are available. For which recognition and appreciation of Takafumi Hiroe, citizen of Japan & naval air historian for all ‘GO!NAVY’ references is deserved)
